DOC.HEAD: Pioneer in Diabetes Research Dies at 89
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Priscilla White, whose research sharply increased the survival rate of babies born to diabetic women, died at age 89 after a long illness. White died Saturday at her home in this Boston suburb, according to a statement from the Joslin Diabetes Center in Boston. Her studies identified ways to decrease the risk of maternal and child death in pregnancies complicated by diabetes, the statement said. White's research and the treatment process she developed increased the fetal survival rate around the country from 54 percent in the 1920s to about 97 percent in the late 1970s and 1980s, it said. Born in Boston, White attended Radcliffe College and graduated third in her class from Tufts University Medical School in 1923. She joined a diabetes practice headed by Elliott P. Joslin, and in 1924 became the youngest member of the team that established the clinic now known as the Joslin Diabetes Center. White taught at Harvard Medical School and was an assistant professor of medicine at Tufts. She received numerous honors, and was the first woman to receive the Banting Medal, the American Diabetes Association's highest scientific award. In her research, White found that a fetus of a diabetic mother often would be healthy a month before delivery but would die if allowed to go full term. She concluded that babies of diabetic women should be delivered by Caesarean section at eight months. She gradually discovered that babies could remain in the womb an extra week to develop. She also learned that although infants of diabetic mothers usually are normal or larger than normal in size despite premature birth, they require the same special care needed for premature infants.
